item.title: Server
item.content:encoded:
import { Aside } from 'astro-pure/user'

I chose a Minisforum AI X1 Pro as my home server. I bought it on Amazon during the Black Friday 2025 discounts, along with 128 GB Crucial DDR5 SODIMM SDRAM and three nvme disks: two 4 TB WD Black SN850X and one 1 TB Crucial T500 Pro (all with heat sinks).

Opening

The installation of all components is trivial. You need to unscrew the screws at the bottom (one is hidden under a rubber pad), then remove the metal case, and finally unscrew the cooler.

Under the cooler and around the power supply, you can find the interfaces of memories and disks.

Memory

There is little room for your fingers, but installing the two RAM memory modules is quite easy.

Disks

Installing NVME disks is also easier.

Closing

That's all, now you can again secure the cooler and metal cover with screws.

item.title: Installation
item.content:encoded:
import { Aside, Steps } from 'astro-pure/user'

Proxmox Virtual Environment is a leading open-source server management platform for virtualization.

Download the installer

I assume you are using a Linux-based computer connected to Internet.

Boot the server

You need to plug a screen and a keyboard and connect your server to Internet to properly install the system.

Configure installation

You can simply follow the installation wizard and customize configuration for your needs. I used the whole Crucial T500 Pro disk (1 TB with ZFS) for the system installation and to store VM and CT images.

Reboot

At the end of the installation process, reboot the server and remove the USB stick. Now you can also unplug screen and keyboard, the Proxmox graphical interface is available as a web application on port 8006.

item.title: Pulse
item.description: A lightweight monitoring application for Proxmox VE.
item.content:encoded:
import { Aside } from 'astro-pure/user'

Pulse is a full-featured real-time monitoring tool for Proxmox, Docker, and Kubernetes infrastructure. I'm using it to monitor Proxmox server, VMs and LXCs, docker containers living inside the VMs.

Installation

Use the helper script and follow the instructions.

Setup

Check the IP assigned to the new LXC container, browse to http://192.168.X.Y:7655, and go to Settings.

Use the auto-discovery feature to locate your Proxmox node, then set it up using Agent install.

With the Proxmox agent you can also monitor VMs and CTs, but if you want more control over processes running inside a VM, you can manually install additional agents in them.

For example, if you use Docker inside a VM, you can monitor status and resources for each container.

item.title: Setup
item.content:encoded:
import { Aside, Steps } from 'astro-pure/user'

There are tons of configurations, but the defaults are pretty good for basic needs. Here I'll focus on my own setup, please refer to the official documentation for further details.

Secure Shell

Sometimes you need to connect to the underlying system (Debian 13 for Proxmox v9) from a console to perform low level operations. I suggest you to properly configure SSH and register your public key to connect without password prompting.

Host *
    ServerAliveInterval 30

Host pve.local
    HostName 192.168.X.X
    User root
    Port 22

Then run ssh-copy-id pve.local once and now you can connect simply using ssh pve.local.

Disks and volumes

My server has three disks: the slower and smaller one (1 TB) is for system, configurations, and VM/CT images, the others two are mounted in RAID0 using ZFS and they are intended for data volumes.

4. Check the pool status: `zpool status -v`
5. Expose the pool to PVE: `pvesm add zfspool local-data --pool zpool` (you can change `local-data` name)

Now I have 8 super-fast terabytes where I can store VM and CT data.

item.title: Cloud
item.content:encoded:
Even though I call myself self-hosting degen, sometimes I need the cloud for basic stuff and to expose public services without too many delivery or security issues.

Basic services

Currently I'm using Cloudflare for domains and DNS, Github for code and static site hosting (yes, I know, I'm working on it), Proton for email services.

VPS

I have two VPSs:

  • a VPS NL-1 by MyNymBox for headscale only
  • a VPS S by IONOS for Zcash exit node

item.title: Networking
item.description: Modem, routers, switches, and access points
item.content:encoded:
My house is connected to the Internet via two connections and two different ISPs: via FTTH at 1 Gbps and via 5G at an average of 300 Mbps.

FTTH

The fiber enters the house on the ground floor and is connected to an ONT and then to the modem with 1 Gbps WAN and LAN ports only. Both are under an uninterruptible power supply by APC.

Multi-WAN router

A Cat8 LAN cable carries the signal to the second floor where I have my lab. Here it's connected to the WAN port of a 1 Gbps multi-WAN router by Cudy.

5G

On the roof I installed a 5G antenna by Kaser that amplifies the input signal to a 5G modem by TP-Link. It's powered by an APC UPS and it's connected to the multi-WAN router as backup connection via a Cat6 cable.

Access point

Finally the multi-WAN router carries the signal to an ASUS ZenWifi router and access point to which my server is connected via a Cat6 cable. Routers and server are powered by another APC UPS.

item.title: Exit nodes
item.content:encoded:
import { Aside, Steps, Tabs, TabItem } from 'astro-pure/user'

Every node that want to join your tailscale network must have Tailscale Client installed (see regular nodes).

Installation

Supposing a GNU/Linux Debian 13 Trixie operating system, you can install it with curl -fsSL https://tailscale.com/install.sh | sh.

Configuration

Then you need to join the network using a running headscale server, but this time you need to declare the node as an exit one.

tailscale up \
    --login-server=https://hs.yourdomain.app \
    --advertise-exit-node \
    --accept-routes \
    --accept-dns=true \
    --hostname=your-node-name

The first time you need to accept the new node following the instructions shown.

Then you can check the list of registered nodes on headscale server with headscale nodes list.

The exit node should be listed also as route: headscale nodes list-routes.

Firewall setup

If your node is exposed to Internet (ie. a VPS with a public IP) and you want to control open ports, you can allow udp traffic on port 41641. Using ufw: ufw allow 41641/udp.

Incoming traffic

If you need to forward incoming traffic to another node on tailscale network, you need to allow forwarding at kernel and firewall level, and incoming traffic on tailscale network interface.

Now you have two options: use a reverse proxy or configure a NAT.

```txt title="/etc/caddy/Caddyfile"
public.yourdomain.app {
    reverse_proxy 100.64.0.X:8080
}
```

Then apply changes: `systemctl restart caddy`.

```txt title="/etc/ufw/before.rules"
*nat
:PREROUTING ACCEPT [0:0]
-A PREROUTING -p tcp --dport 9999 -j DNAT --to-destination 100.64.0.X:9999
-A POSTROUTING -p tcp -d 100.64.0.X --dport 9999 -j MASQUERADE
COMMIT
```

<Aside type="caution">
    This `*nat` block should be on top of the file before `*filter` block!
    And don't forget the `COMMIT`!
</Aside>

Of course the port must be open: `ufw allow 9999/tcp`.

Then apply changes: `systemctl restart ufw`.

Kernel tweaks

Update the Generic Receive Offload (GRO) settings if needed.

See the official documentation for details.

item.title: Headscale
item.description: An open source, self-hosted implementation of the Tailscale control server.
item.content:encoded:
import { Aside, Steps } from 'astro-pure/user'

Headscale's goal is to provide self-hosters and hobbyists with an open-source server they can use for their projects and labs. It implements a narrow scope, a single Tailscale network (tailnet), suitable for a personal use, or a small open-source organisation.

I'm going to use a VPS NL-1 by MyNymBox, so 1 vCPU, 512 MB of RAM, 10 GB of disk, and 1 TB of traffic per month. Headscale should only coordinate nodes, so these requirements should be sufficient for tens or few hundreds of nodes.

Getting started

My operating system of choice is GNU/Linux Debian 13 Trixie. I suggest to update the system at the very first login: apt update && apt dist-upgrade.

SSH client

First of all, save server details in SSH config on your computer.

Host *
    ServerAliveInterval 30

Host hs.remote
    HostName X.X.X.X
    User root
    Port 22

Then enable SSH login via public key with ssh-copy-id hs.remote and now you can connect simply using ssh hs.remote.

SSH server

Changing SSH port is a best practice to avoid malicious bot traffic. On the server edit the SSH server config in /etc/ssh/sshd_config.

# A random port number between 1024 and 65535
Port 49876
# Disable password login, use only public key
PermitRootLogin prohibit-password

Restart SSH server with systemctl restart sshd and terminate connection.

Change host port in your ~/.ssh/config and login again.

Installation

We need two services: Headscale and Caddy.

Headscale

The default and recommended way to install headscale is using official .deb packages (see the official documentation).

Caddy

Headscale has to be publicly reachable by nodes, so we need to expose it to external traffic via https. We will use Caddy as reverse proxy and to automatically manage TLS termination (see the official documentation).

Install it from official repository: apt install caddy.

Configuration

Headscale

Main configuration is stored in /etc/headscale/config.yaml file.

# Public domain, you need to register it and control the DNS
server_url: https://hs.yourdomain.app
dns:
    # If you want to use domain names such as headscale.home.yourdomain.app
    # for your nodes inside the tailscale network instead of 100.64.0.X
    magic_dns: true
    # You can use any valid domain name, not related to your server_url
    base_domain: home.yourdomain.app
    override_local_dns: true

Now apply the new configuration: systemctl enable --now headscale. Check if headscale daemon is running as expected: systemctl status headscale.

Create the user the network nodes will belong to: headscale users create your_name. Check if it exists: headscale users list.

Caddy

Edit the configuration file: /etc/caddy/Caddyfile.

hs.yourdomain.app {
    reverse_proxy 127.0.0.1:8080
}

Apply the new configuration: systemctl restart caddy.

DNS

Your domain need to be resolved to your VPS's public IPs (IPv4 and IPv6), so you need to add these DNS records for yourdomain.app.

A    hs X.X.X.X
AAAA hs X:X:X:X::X

Now a request sent to https://hs.yourdomain.app is managed by Caddy on your VPS: automatic TLS certificates management, TLS termination, reverse proxy to headscale.

Final steps

SSH server needs custom port 49876, caddy needs public ports 80 (http) and 443 (https), tailscale needs port 41641 for udp traffic.

Setup a firewall that closes all ports but those really needed is strongly suggested.

item.title: Overview
item.description: A Zero Trust identity-based connectivity platform
item.content:encoded:
Tailscale is a full-featured solution for peer-to-peer networks powered by WireGuard tunnels.

I have two stringent requirements that a solution like Tailscale meets very well:

  1. I don't want that remote servers know my real IP when I send requests from a service hosted by my home server
  2. I want that a service running on my home server is publicly (and securely) reachable from outside without opening my router ports

Tailscale Inc. offers a full-managed cloud-based solution, but client-side and server-side code is open, so I managed to self-host my own solution.

item.title: Helper scripts
item.description: Manage and execute Proxmox helper scripts locally with live output streaming
item.content:encoded:
PVE Helper Scripts is a valuable project that simplifies Proxmox management. You can search for the script you need using the official repository, but I chose to install it locally.

Installation

From the server shell, run the following script that spins up a pre-configured LXC container.

bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/community-scripts/ProxmoxVE/main/ct/pve-scripts-local.sh)"

Check the IP assigned to the new LXC container and browse to http://192.168.X.Y:3000.

Usage

You can browse the repository and search for the scripts you need. Then you can download and run them from the web interface.

The first one I suggest you to run is PVE Post Install.

This script provides options for managing Proxmox VE repositories, including disabling the Enterprise Repo, adding or correcting PVE sources, enabling the No-Subscription Repo, adding the test Repo, disabling the subscription nag, updating Proxmox VE, and rebooting the system.
